abstract.text: The object you use to manage the setup, configuration, and teardown of your networking driver.

inlineContent.text: Subclass

and override the methods you need to implement your driver’s behavior. Your subclass manages your driver’s overall life cycle, and facilitates communication between the hardware and the rest of the system. Use the
method to establish a link to your hardware and to create the data structures needed to manage incoming and outgoing data packets. Use the
method to clean up the data structures you create in your
method.
Override other methods of this class, and of the
parent class, as needed to enable your interface and implement other network-related behaviors. For example, you might want to override the inherited
method to respond to power-level changes.
When you subclass
, update the
key of your driver extension’s
file with information to match your driver to appropriate hardware. For this class, always include the keys and values in the following table.
Key
Discussion
The value
The provider class information. For USB-based network interfaces, specify
The name of your custom subclass.
The bundle identifier of your driver.
The value
You may add other keys to assist with the matching process. For example, you might include the
, and

keys to match against specific USB device attributes. The USB specification defines which keys to include when matching your driver to a USB device. For information about the specific key combinations, see
Universal Serial Bus Common Class Specification

abstract.text: A unique identifier for a bundle.
A provider object that manages interactions with an interface of the USB device.
The base class for managing the setup and registration of your driver.
Requests a power managed driver to change the power state of its device.
Starts the current service and associates it with the specified provider.
Stops the service associated with the specified provider.
Develop drivers for Ethernet networking devices.
The object you use to manage the setup, configuration, and teardown of your networking driver.
Registers your driver with the networking stack.
Tells the system what types of networking media your driver supports.
Reports the input and output bandwidth between the device and your driver to the system.
Reports the quality of the link between the device and your driver to the system.
Reports the status of the link between the device and your driver to the system.
Selects the media type to use when communicating with the network stack.
Enables or disables multicast support for your service.
Enables or disables your service.
Sets the device addresses to use for multicast filtering.
Enables or disables support for monitoriong all network packets.
Enables software VLAN support.
Reserves the specified number of bytes at the front of each packet.
Reserves the specified number of bytes at the end of each packet.
Enables or disables support for waking up the device when a specially formatted packet arrives.
Tells the system whether the device supports being woken up when a specially formatted packet arrives.
Performs any final cleanup for the service.
Handles the basic initialization of the service.
A type for specifying the quality of your device’s connection to the host.
A type for specifying the state of your device’s connection.
A hardware address for a device.
A structure describing a specific Ethernet type and configuration that your driver supports.
The base class for managing the setup and registration of your driver.
